choices.text: Macule - Primary lesion; raised solid lesion >1 cm
Ulcer - Primary lesion, heals without scarring
Vesicle - Secondary lesion; fluid-filled lesion >1 cm

questions.text: Which of the following lesions is correctly matched with its type and description?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Nodule is a circumscribed solid primary lesion with depth more than width.

Primary lesions:

  • Flat, non-palpable, change in color of skin <1cm → macule, >1cm → patch (Option A ruled out).
  • Circumscribed, solid, raised<1cm → papule, >1cm → plaque, Depth > width →nodule.
  • Clear, fluid filled<1cm → vesicle, >1cm → bulla (Option D ruled out).

Secondary lesions:

  • Ulcer: Full thickness loss of epidermis, Basement membrane: Not intact (Option C ruled out).
    • Reaches dermis, Heals with scarring

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with chronic eczema presents with thickened, leathery skin over her forearms due to repeated scratching. Histological examination reveals accentuation of normal skin markings. Lichenification in this condition primarily affects which layer of the skin?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Lichenification is a thickening of the skin with exaggerated skin markings due to chronic scratching or rubbing involving the stratum malpighii.

  • Can be primary (lichen simplex chronicus) or secondary (e.g., due to eczema).
  • Age: Peak incidence between 30–50 years; seen from adolescence onwards.
  • Sex: More common in women.
  • Pathology
    • Involves Stratum Malpighii (includes stratum basale + stratum spinosum) showing:
      • Hyperplasia (epidermal thickening involving all layers).
      • Acanthosis (thickened stratum spinosum).
      • Hyperkeratosis (thickened stratum corneum).
      • Elongated rete ridges, often irregular.
      • Spongiosis may be present.
      • Parakeratosis may be seen in some areas.

Explanation of other options:

Stratum corneum (Option B) : While hyperkeratosis may be present, it's not the primary layer responsible for lichenification.

Stratum lucidum (Option C) : Present only in thick skin (palms and soles); not involved in typical lichenification.

Stratum granulosum (Option D) : May show some thickening (hypergranulosis) in chronic dermatitis, but the main change occurs in stratum malpighii.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man returns from a beach vacation in southern India. A few days later, he develops an intensely itchy, raised, red lesion on his leg as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Cutaneous Larva Migrans (CLM) is a dermatitis caused by the invasion and migration of larvae (mainly nematodes) into the skin.

  • Causative Organisms:
    • Most commonly caused by larval nematodes.
    • Rarely caused by insect larvae.
  • Characteristic Feature:
    • The lesion migrates or "creeps" through the skin.
    • This is due to the active movement of larvae within the superficial layers of the skin.
  • Transmission:
    • Occurs when larvae penetrate the skin, typically via bare feet or exposed skin in contaminated environments (e.g., sand, soil).
  • The most common initial finding is a small reddish papule that progresses to a serpiginous pruritic rash with a slow rate of progression from less than 1 to 2 cm per day.

Explanation for other options:

Psoriasis (Option B) typically presents with well-demarcated, erythematous plaques covered with silvery-white scales, commonly seen on the extensor surfaces (elbows, knees) and scalp. It is not migratory and does not form serpiginous patterns. Lesions are stable or slowly enlarging, not rapidly creeping.

Lichen planus (Option C) manifests as violaceous (purple), flat-topped, polygonal papules, often with fine white lines (Wickham striae). It does not migrate or creep. Lesions are symmetrical and discrete, not serpiginous or advancing.

Urticaria (Option D) causes transient, itchy wheals due to histamine-mediated oedema. Lesions appear and disappear quickly, often within 24 hours. They are not slowly migrating or track-like. Typically not serpiginous, and there's no history of travel-related skin penetration.

--

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman presents with depigmented patches over her hands and face. On Wood's lamp examination, the patches show milky white fluorescence. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Vitiligo shows milky white fluorescence on Wood's lamp examination.

  • The 'milky white' fluorescence seen in vitiligo under Wood's lamp is due to the complete absence of melanin in the depigmented areas.
  • Melanin normally absorbs ultraviolet (UV) light (365 nm).
  • In vitiligo, melanocytes are destroyed, so the skin has no melanin.
  • Without melanin to absorb UV, the light reflects back, making the skin appear bright white or milky under Wood's lamp.
  • The surrounding normal pigmented skin absorbs UV and appears darker, increasing the contrast.

Wood's lamp:

  • Helps in visualizing subtle skin changes not apparent under normal light.
  • Light source : UV lights
  • Wavelength: 360-365nm
  • Glass: Barium silicate with 9% nickel oxide

Fluorescence Findings

  1. Tinea capitis - Blue green fluorescence
  2. Pityriasis versicolor - pale yellow fluorescence (Option A ruled out)
  3. Erythrasma - coral red (Option D ruled out)
  4. Melasma: Accentuation of the lesion
  5. Vitiligo: Ivory white (Option B)
  6. Congenital erythropoietic porphyria: Red teeth Erythrodontia

Pityriasis alba (Option C ruled out) may show no fluorescence or slight accentuation.

questions.text: A dermatologist presses a glass slide over a reddish-brown skin lesion, which blanches on pressure as shown below. This technique is useful in distinguishing between erythema and purpura. What is this diagnostic method called?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

  • Diascopy: Pressing a glass slide or a stiff, clear, colourless piece of plastic onto the skin to cause blanching by compressing blood out of small vessels. This allows colours to be seen.
  • Use of diascopy:
    • Apple jelly nodules: yellow brown lesions seen in lupus vulgaris and sarcoidosis
    • Spider naevi: compression of radiating arterioles
    • Differentiation of erythema and purpura
    • Differentiation of nevus anemicus from nevus achromicus

Garattage test (Option A) - Used to assess Auspitz sign in psoriasis, involving scraping of scales.

Scratch sign (Option B) - Seen in urticaria pigmentosa (mastocytosis), where stroking the skin causes wheal formation (Darier's sign), unrelated to blanching.

Patch test (Option D) - Used to diagnose contact allergic dermatitis by applying allergens to the skin and checking for delayed hypersensitivity reactions.

choices.text: The test chambers used are made of stainless steel
The first reading is taken immediately after 12 hours
The chambers used are known as Finn chambers and are made of aluminium
Distilled water is the most commonly used diluent for test allergens

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with chronic hand eczema undergoes patch testing as shown below to identify possible allergens. Regarding this test, which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Multiple patch tests are applied to the back during patch testing.
  • The tested materials, purchased in an appropriate concentration (mostly diluted in petrolatum) for testing, are applied to 8 mm diameter aluminium Finn chambers. (Options A and D ruled out)
  • These patches are left on for two days, removed and read, and then read again after another two days (that is, four days after first being applied).
  • Reading is done at 48 and 96 hours. (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman is undergoing excision of a benign skin lesion on her abdomen. The surgeon uses the orientation of lines shown in the image to plan the incision, aiming to minimise scarring and promote optimal healing. What anatomical concept do these lines represent?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

  • Langer's lines/Relaxed skin tension lines/cleavage lines, are topological lines drawn on a map of the human body.
  • They are parallel to the natural orientation of collagen fibres in the dermis and generally perpendicular to the underlying muscle fibres.
  • Incisions made parallel to Langer's lines heal better and produce less scarring than those that cut across.
  • Conversely, incisions perpendicular to Langer's lines have a tendency to gape and heal with hypertrophic/keloid scars.

Explanation of other options:

Blaschko lines (Option A) represent developmental patterns of skin cell migration. The shape stays constant throughout life. Blaschko's lines represent a classic pattern of cutaneous mosaicism (two or more genetically different populations of cells existing side by side), occurring in a wide variety of congenital and acquired skin conditions.

Marionette lines (Option B) are age-related wrinkles extending from the corners.

Dermatomes (Option C): Skin areas innervated by specific spinal nerves.

questions.text: A pediatric dermatologist is evaluating a child with a linear, hypopigmented lesion following a Blaschko's distribution. Which of the following dermatoses is least likely to follow Blaschko's lines?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Nevus of Ito is a dermal melanocytosis, typically presenting as bluish-grey pigmentation in the distribution of the posterior supraclavicular and lateral cutaneous brachial nerves, not following Blaschko's lines.

Blaschko's lines represent pathways of embryonic cell migration and are commonly followed by several cutaneous conditions. These lines are invisible under normal conditions but become apparent in various congenital or acquired dermatoses.

Dermatoses along Blaschko's lines

  • Incontinentia pigmenti (Option A ruled out)
  • Epidermal nevi (Option D ruled out)
  • Hypomelanosis of Ito (Option C ruled out)
  • Lichen striatus
  • ILVEN (Inflammatory linear verrucous epidermal nevus)
  • Linear psoriasis
  • Linear lichen planus
  • Adult-onset blaschkitis
